subject: RE: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
msgSnippet: ...  If a programmer changes the implementation from trivial to nontrivial, add some tests. If a programmer change the implementation from nontrivial
messageBody:
>So said Robert Brown on 4/24/2003 --------------------
>In my opinion, you should test every public method of a class. The
>reason I have for this is that even though you know that the method
>turns around and calls another method that is tested somewhere else,
>that may not always be the case, and you don't know that the call is
>coded correctly either, or that the underlying class/method hasn't been
>changed to return something that is unexpected.
<snip />

If a programmer changes the implementation from trivial to nontrivial, add some tests. If a programmer change the implementation from nontrivial to trivial, remove some tests. That may seem wasteful, but in my opinion, testing trivial code is more wasteful over time.

Take care.


J. B. Rainsberger,
President, Diaspar Software Services
Let's write software that people understand.
http://www.diasparsoftware.com/
